H0.text: Limited resources caused the cricket population to shift from an equal number of black and light‑brown crickets to only light‑brown crickets over time, as black crickets are easier for birds to locate and eat.

H1.text: Natural selection is the process that caused a cricket population that initially had roughly equal numbers of black and light‑brown individuals to evolve to consist only of light‑brown crickets, because black crickets were more readily eaten by birds.

H2.text: Geographic isolation is the result of the change in color of the cricket population, which began with roughly equal numbers of black and light‑brown crickets, black crickets being easier for birds to locate and eat, and over time the population came to consist only of light‑brown crickets.

H3.text: Climate change is the result of the change in the color of the cricket population, which initially included roughly equal numbers of black and light‑brown crickets, but over time came to consist only of light‑brown crickets because black crickets were more easily located and eaten by birds.

A4.text: Pale individuals more closely match lichen backgrounds than dark morphs

A5.text: The balance was reversed by the effect of the Clean Air Act 1956, and the dark moths became rare again, demonstrating the influence of natural selection on peppered moth evolution
